title: Sírlám
text: Sírlám, son of <a href="Finn%20mac%20Blatha">Finn mac Blatha</a>, was, according to medieval Irish legend and historical tradition, a <a href="High%20King%20of%20Ireland">High King of Ireland</a>. He took power after killing his predecessor, <a href="Lugaid%20%C3%8Dardonn">Lugaid Íardonn</a>, in Ráth Clochair. His name means "long hand" or "long arm", and it is said his arms reached the ground when was standing up (compare the Irish <a href="deity">god</a> <a href="Lugh">Lug</a>, whose <a href="epithet">epithet</a> "lámfada" also means "long arm"). He ruled for thirteen years according to the "<a href="Lebor%20Gab%C3%A1la%20%C3%89renn">Lebor Gabála Érenn</a>", or sixteen according to <a href="Geoffrey%20Keating">Geoffrey Keating</a> and the <a href="Annals%20of%20the%20Four%20Masters">Four Masters</a>. He drove Lugaid's son <a href="Eochu%20Uairches">Eochu Uairches</a> into exile, but after twelve years overseas Eochu returned and killed him with an arrow. The "Lebor Gabála" synchronises his reign with that of <a href="Artaxerxes%20I%20of%20Persia">Artaxerxes I of Persia</a> (465–424 BC). The chronology of Keating's "Foras Feasa ar Éirinn" dates his reign to 649–633 BC, that of the "Annals of the Four Masters" to 872–856 BC.
